description: A respelling, probably influenced by cake, of nokehick, nokehike, which derives from an Algonquian language, probably Narragansett nokehick or Massachusett nookhik (“nocake”, literally “(that which is) pounded till soft”); the word is related to Abenaki nokhigan (“flour”), and English rokeag and yokeag.

entries.meaning: Indian corn parched and pounded into meal (powder), used as food by Native Americans, sometimes mixed with maple sugar.
examples: Synonyms: nokehick, nokehike, rokeag, yokeag, rokeage, yokeage
